supporting.text: Kim Il-sung died in 1994, long before LinkedIn was founded in 2002, making it impossible for him to have used the platform.

attacks.text: Kim Il-sung died in 1994, long before LinkedIn was founded in 2002, making it impossible for him to have used the platform.
The claim could be interpreted metaphorically, suggesting someone else used his name or legacy on LinkedIn.
Metaphorical interpretations of historical figures on professional platforms are highly unlikely and lack evidence.

supporting.text: North Korea has strict internet controls, and LinkedIn is not accessible to its citizens, let alone its leaders.

attacks.text: North Korea has strict internet controls, and LinkedIn is not accessible to its citizens, let alone its leaders.
Some North Korean elites have limited, monitored internet access for diplomatic or business purposes.
Even if elites have access, LinkedIn would likely be blocked due to its potential for unauthorized external communication.
Kim Il-sung died in 1994, long before LinkedIn was founded in 2002.

supporting.text: There is no historical record or credible evidence suggesting Kim Il-sung ever used any social media platform.

attacks.text: There is no historical record or credible evidence suggesting Kim Il-sung ever used any social media platform.
Kim Il-sung died in 1994, before LinkedIn or most modern social media platforms were founded.
Even if LinkedIn existed during Kim Il-sung's lifetime, North Korea's extreme isolation would have prevented access to such platforms.
Hypothetically, a foreign diplomat could have created a profile on Kim Il-sung's behalf without his knowledge.

supporting.text: LinkedIn is a professional networking site, and Kim Il-sung's political role and isolationist policies make it highly unlikely he would have engaged with such a platform.

attacks.text: LinkedIn is a professional networking site, and Kim Il-sung's political role and isolationist policies make it highly unlikely he would have engaged with such a platform.
Historical records show that North Korean leaders, including Kim Il-sung, have used foreign platforms for propaganda or diplomatic purposes when it suited their interests.
